newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Upward pressure on Dutch money rates seen fading.
newsitem.headline: Upward pressure on Dutch money rates seen fading.

text.p: Dutch money rates edged up in an overall quiet market as Belgium, France and the U.S. closed on Monday.
Dealers said rates were slightly higher as traders started clearing their books near the end of the year, but said the rise in rates was likely to come to a halt.
"The Dutch state has raised quite a lot of liquidity through its Dutch Treasury Certificates programmes and comparatively, needs little more," said one dealer.
The Dutch 1996 borrowing requirement was set at 39.1 billion guilders, of which 28.0 billion guilders has been raised through bond issues.
DTCs, the short-term borrowing programme, have added another 10.1 billion guilders, dealers said.
"This could mean that the Dutch state only needs another one billion guilders in 1996," said one dealer. But other market participants said it could be slightly more.
"Slowing demand from the state could lessen the upward pressure on Dutch deposits," said one dealer.
Call money rates were stable at a bid range between 2.62-68 percent.
Three-month deposits rose two basis points to 2.92 percent bid and six-month paper added four basis points to 3.02 percent.
Dealers said some trades in three-month deposits were done at 3.02 percent. "Japanese banks usually accept a higher rate," said one dealer.
The guilder was at 112.1375 per 100 marks from 112.175 on Friday.
